awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Coronavirus Risk Communication: How Age and Communication Format Affect Risk Perception and Behaviors
awd_abstract_narration:
On March 11, 2020 the coronavirus officially became a global pandemic. In the United States the suggestion to practice “social distancing” was replaced by official “stay at home” orders from at least 30 states, and numerous counties and cities. Despite these official orders, people continued to gather in outdoor spaces and in private. Why do they do so? Are they “risk seeking” in the sense that they understand the risk but have decided to take it anyway? Or do they misunderstand the risk of contracting the disease, becoming seriously ill, or spreading it to others? Given the complexity and variability of the information about coronavirus available to the public, misunderstandings are likely. It may be difficult for individuals to assess their own risk of contracting and/or dying from the disease, and particularly difficult to understand the risk of passing it on to others. Nonetheless, one thing is clear: older people are at a greater risk for fatality. The risk for contracting the disease, however, appears to be more evenly distributed across age groups. It is possible that people use an unconscious simplifying strategy focusing on the more dramatic and widely publicized death rates and assume that if they are younger, all risks, including those that they pose to others, are less. The first goal of this project is to assess the perceived risks associated with coronavirus across age groups and determine how risk perception impacts the decisions people make. The second goal is to design and test risk expressions that are understandable to members of the public. Thus, this project makes significant contributions to our understanding of how people make risky decisions in context, based on complex risk information, as well as to the development of communication strategies tailored for different users.
 
Successful risk communication strategies depend upon first understanding how people process complex risk information. In the context of the coronavirus, decision makers must take into account both the risk to themselves as well as the risk to others they may infect if they contract the coronavirus. There are numerous cognitive issues associated with this process that at present are not well understood. In particular, how do people understand related but differing risk estimates? How do they use that information to make precautionary decisions that impact themselves as well as others? This project conducts a series of online studies to determine how people perceive coronavirus risks, separately and in combination, as well as how risk perception impacts their precautionary decisions. Perhaps more importantly, based on preliminary surveys, understandable risk communication expressions are developed and tested experimentally to establish causal links between information expression and risk perception, trust, and decisions. Finally, using a few relevant individual difference measures, the researchers determine whether specific abilities are necessary to process complex numeric risk expressions and whether simplified expressions are better in some cases. The results of this work provide invaluable advice with the potential to save lives. This research can inform best practices in risk communication that have important implications for communicating risks in future outbreaks. Understanding how best to communicate risks to the public and whether communication should be tailored to specific subgroups is critical to avoiding future pandemics.

por.por_cntn:
Critical to limiting the spread of Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID- 19) and future pandemics is compliance with behavioral recommendations such as mask wearing, vaccination, and social distancing. Compliance may depend upon understanding the seriousness of the health consequences, the likelihood they will occur, and the safety of the measures such as vaccination. We explored these issues in five experiments, the first three focused on risk perception early in the pandemic. The last two investigated messaging to increase vaccination rates.

The statistics that speak to risk in an ongoing pandemic are complex and may be misunderstood. One major goal of the first three studies was to determine how risk messaging, based on the statistics available early in the pandemic, impacted peoples' perception of the likelihood of contracting or dying from COVID-19 and participants' willingness to engage in protective actions like mask wearing and social distancing.

In two online experiments conducted in May and June 2020 with 3,634 Americans, we tested the impact of risk messages on risk perception, willingness to take protective measures (e.g., mask wearing, social distancing), and agreement with government response. The biggest issue at the time was the contrast between the disease outcomes for older and younger people. Therefore, infection messages described the percentage of those older and younger than 50 years of age, among all those who had tested positive for COVID-19. Mortality messages described the percentage of all those who died of COVID-19, who were older and younger than 50. We also tested messages that described both (mortality and infection). We tested numeric expressions that described the percentage in each age group and gist messages that indicated which group was smaller (mortality) or that they were roughly equivalent (infection).

We found for younger participants, providing both mortality and infection statistics in the gist message increased willingness to wear masks indoors, perhaps because it made clear that although they were less likely to die from COVID-19, they were equally likely to be infected and spread it. We also found that government restrictions (social distance, stay at home) were effective. They increased willingness to wear a mask among younger participants and decreased willingness to engage in risk seeking activities (e.g., go to gym) for the group as a whole. Surprisingly, there was no difference detected in effectiveness of restrictions due to political ideology, suggesting that these kinds of measures may be widely, if not universally effective. Although we expected younger participants to be much more willing to engage in risky behaviors than older participants, this was not so. Instead, the largest difference was due to political ideology. Conservatives were much less will willing to engage in protective behaviors like mask wearing than were liberals, although they perceived similar COVID-19 risks.

Two later experiments focused on vaccine-hesitancy among 5,354 unvaccinated Americans in April and July 2021, after those 18 years and older became eligible for the COVID-19 vaccines. Previous research suggested that the greatest barrier to vaccination for some people may be fear of the vaccine itself. This could be due to misunderstandings about the vaccines, arising from complexities of the science involved. Therefore, the goal of these experiments was to test simple explanations correcting known misunderstandings to see if they increased willingness to get the COVID-19 vaccine compared to a no-information group.

Indeed, these unvaccinated individuals were less concerned about the threat of the disease than about the safety of the vaccine. This asymmetry in concerns may be characteristic of the vaccine hesitant and as such, could inform communications strategies going forward. Importantly, in both studies we found that explanations of issues such as the incidence and nature of vaccine side effects and the mechanism by which mRNA vaccines provide protection, presented in everyday language, were effective. They increased willingness to get vaccinated, regardless of political ideology (Figure 1). Interestingly, among the explanations that was most effective was a lengthy text that combined these side effects and mechanism explanations and included refutational text. Refutational text explicitly points out the misunderstanding (Some people think X, but that is not true) and corrects it. Refutational text may be especially effective in cases in which such misunderstandings are repeatedly reinforced and/or based on assumptions of which decision makers are not fully aware. Guiding people through the reasoning process step-by-step may be necessary to correct the misunderstanding and change attitudes.

This research has important implications for communicating information to unvaccinated individuals and communicating health information in general. Although there are many who believe that 'less is more' in risk communication, the research reported here suggests the opposite, that complex scientific explanations can be effective in reducing concerns and increasing willingness to get vaccinated. Such explanations can allow people to appreciate the relevant scientific facts, overcome dangerous misunderstandings, and make better decisions for themselves and others.
